thread.title: CIA Secret Surveillance Operation Named After 'Doctor Who'
thread.title_full: CIA Secret Surveillance Operation Named After 'Doctor Who' - Geek.com

author: Stephanie Mlot
title: CIA Secret Surveillance Operation Named After 'Doctor Who'
text:
BBC Stay on target Four Doctors Battle Cybermen in 50th Anniversary Comics 3 New ‘Doctor Who’ Novels Chase Season 10 Premiere Don’t blink: Did the Central Intelligence Agency name a secret surveillance operation after Doctor Who ?
A fresh set of confidential documents —courtesy of WikiLeaks—details tools used by the CIA to break into phones, smart televisions, and other Web-connected devices, apps, and operating systems.
One such program that’s garnered mass attention: “ Weeping Angel .”
BBC
The scheme allegedly relies on a hidden Samsung Smart TV feature, which allows agents to remotely suppress the set, making it appear to be turned off when it is actually recording audio conversations.
The CIA is staying mum about leak (a spokesman told The New York Times that “we do not comment on the authenticity or content of purported intelligence documents”). But some believe the so-called “ Weeping Angel ” operation was named for one of the Doctor’s most frightening foes.
According to the document—which bears the CIA crest and calls the operation “secret”—Weeping Angel was discussed during a joint workshop with the UK’s MI5/BTSS (British Security Service) in June 2014.
“The attack against Samsung smart TVs was developed in cooperation” with the British government, WikiLeaks said in an analysis of the documents.
And while US and UK intelligence agencies insist code names are randomly chosen by a computer, not based on personal pop culture preferences, it’s hard to believe this particular title wasn’t at least influenced by the long-running BBC sci-fi show.
Known as “The Lonely Assassins,” Doctor Who ‘s Weeping Angels are quantum-locked alien killers: The innocuous-looking statues freeze when observed, but move lickety-split in the blink of an eye. One touch and you’re flung back in time, allowing the Angel to feed on the energy of your unlived days.
The beautiful-if-ghastly creatures first appeared in the 2007 episode “Blink,” featuring Carey Mulligan as Sally Sparrow, who must follow the Tenth Doctor’s cryptic clues to trap the Weeping Angels and release the TARDIS.
Perhaps the CIA recognized some latent similarities between the stone-cold monsters and their surveillance program. Or maybe someone in the agency’s IT department a huge Doctor Who fan.
Other found document labels include Brutal Kangaroo, Fine Dining, Cutthroat and Swindle, HammerDrill, and HarpyEagle.
Stream all of Doctor Who now for free with your Amazon Prime membership.
